title: How to Tie a Noose

steps.headline: Place the rope on a flat surface in the shape of the letter "C." Find a durable rope that is at least three feet long.
Form an "S" shape with the rope.
steps.description: Leave the lead of the rope (the bottom part of the "S") long so that you can tie it to something when you've made the noose.

steps.headline: Compress the "S" shape.
steps.description: Compress the "S" shape until all three rows of rope are nearly on top of each other, with only a few inches in between them.

steps.headline: Pinch the three lines of rope together in the middle.
steps.description: Pinch them tightly until the ends fan out to create a bow-tie effect.

steps.headline: Take the top of the original "C" and wrap it around the pinched space.
steps.description: Wrap it from the right side to the left, leaving about three to four inches of the rope unwrapped. You should be left with a loop and a string on the left end, and just a loop on the right end of the "bow tie."

steps.headline: Poke the end of the rope through the top of the loop left by the "S".
Pinch the coiled part of the rope.
steps.description: Use your thumb to hold down the short piece of rope that you just worked through the loop on the left-hand side so it bends over the loop.

steps.headline: Pull the loop on the right-hand side of the bow until it closes the loop on the left.
steps.description: If this part of the loop begins to pull on the free rope instead of the loop, pull on the other side of the bow.

steps.headline: Adjust the noose.
steps.description: Adjust the noose until the coils look nice and tight and the loop is the size you wanted.

steps.headline: Use the noose wisely.
steps.description: Don't use it on yourself or others—not even as a joke. Use the noose for a Halloween decoration, or when you're fishing or boating.

Compress the "S" shape until all three rows of rope are nearly on top of each other, with only a few inches in between them. Pinch the three lines of rope together in the middle.
